article.title: Working with hardware sensors
article.para: To measure the CPU temperature, install and configure the sensors tool that can access and read the hardware sensors.

step.para: To detect all the sensors in the system, run the following command as &rootuser;:
The --auto allows checking for all hardware monitoring chips at once without probing them one by one. When finished, the script shows a summary of what chips were detected:
step.screen:
Now follows a summary of the probes I have just done.
Driver `coretemp': * Chip `Intel digital thermal sensor' (confidence: 9)
Driver `to-be-written': * ISA bus, address 0xa40 Chip `ITE IT8686E Super IO Sensors' (confidence: 9)
Do you want to generate /etc/sysconfig/lm_sensors? (YES/no):

step.para: Confirm to generate the file /etc/sysconfig/lm_sensors. After confirmation, the script creates a &systemd; service (/usr/lib/systemd/system/lm_sensors.service.) that is enabled by default.

article.para: Check the status of the &systemd; service:
article.screen:
&prompt.sudo;systemctl status lm_sensors ● lm_sensors.service - Initialize hardware monitoring sensors Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/lm_sensors.service; enabled; vendor preset: disabled) Active: active (exited) since Fri 2021-09-10 16:57:55 CEST; 2min 23s ago Process: 32552 ExecStart=/usr/bin/sensors -s (code=exited, status=0/SUCCESS) Process: 32551 ExecStart=/sbin/modprobe -qab $BUS_MODULES $HWMON_MODULES (code=exited, status=0/SUCCESS) Main PID: 32552 (code=exited, status=0/SUCCESS) Tasks: 0 CGroup: /system.slice/lm_sensors.service
Sep 10 16:57:55 edison systemd[1]: Starting Initialize hardware monitoring sensors... Sep 10 16:57:55 edison systemd[1]: Started Initialize hardware monitoring sensors.
article.para: After you have completed these steps, your computer has detected all sensors and has started to monitor them.
